thread.title: Florida ranks 4th for Advanced Placement success
thread.title_full: Florida ranks 4th for Advanced Placement success

author: Leslie Postal
title: Florida ranks 4th for Advanced Placement success

organizations.name: orlando news now  a seminole county schools

text:
Florida ranks 4th for Advanced Placement success For Central Fla. students, AP classes a popular path for collegiate success 
Rebekah Krausman, a math teacher at Winter Springs High School, talks about the importance of her students taking AP classes to prepare for college-level courses, Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel) 
Rebekah Krausman, a math teacher at Winter Springs High School, talks about the importance of her students taking AP classes to prepare for college-level courses, Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel) Leslie Postal in the fall.
AP classes help students “learn the work ethic” they’ll need in college, she added. 
San Filippo is taking seven AP classes this year and has taken plenty in prior years, too. She has passed most of her AP exams but stumbled last year on the AP physics 1 exam. The class, led by a “fantastic” teacher, was still worthwhile, she said. 
“I think most people are in it for the teachers and the high-level classes,” she said. 
In fact, her AP calculus teacher, Rebekah Krausman, is why so many Winter Springs students take the upper-level math classes, she said.. “She’s really passionate about it. She really cares.” 
In class, Krausman seems eager to make sure her students understand the material. “Anyone else?” she asked. “Even if it’s a little one, ask me a question.” 
Krausman’s passing rates are high, but like other educators she said she is confident all her students benefit, even those who do not pass. “It’s preparing them for college courses,” she said. 
At East Ridge, Assistant Principal Stacy Keaveny, who oversees the school’s AP offerings, said AP enrollment grew as more students were encouraged to sign up. 
“Obviously we don’t want to put a student in a class that’s setting them up for failure,” she said. 
But the school has found that many more students than once thought can tackle the material. And as Williams’ AP calculus scores showed, some can meet the challenge of the exams, even when their past academic performance suggests they might not. 
“They get hungry,” Williams said. “Motivating them is really what’s the key.” 
lpostal@orlandosentinel.com 407-420-5273
